reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s move from meta-ethical/intertheoretic uncertainty to comparatively confident practical takeaways (e.g., that ‘fair’ comparisons make fussy/unbounded views loom larger). That is moderately central: it bears on how action-guiding and robust the headline ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion is, but it doesn’t directly undercut the paper’s substantial object-level case that many plausible first-order moral views are fussy and that value can be fragile (those arguments could stand even if we suspend intertheoretic aggregation). Strength is moderate: it plausibly shows the paper’s practical confidence should be more conditional and that alternative moral-uncertainty frameworks could reduce the dominance of fussy/unbounded theories, but it doesn’t demonstrate that the paper’s preferred approaches are wrong or that ‘no easy eutopia’ fails under most reasonable meta-ethical treatments. Correctness is high: it’s true that intertheoretic comparison/normalization is contested and can flip recommendations, and that this weakens unconditional policy confidence; the critique slightly overstates by implying the headline claim is only meaningful if it survives meta-ethical variance (the claim can be presented as conditional, as the paper partly already does). The critique is clear, focused, and has little dead weight; multiple alternative frameworks are cited but all support the same single underlying objection.
title: Moral uncertainty undermines the paper's practical confidence
